docs.snippet: WHEN Roberto Calvi, president of the largest private bank in Italy, was found hanged beneath London's Blackfriars Bridge last June, the shock of the death was heightened by the revelation that followed: Mr. Calvi, with the support of the Vatican, had...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Roberto Calvi, president of the largest private bank in Italy, was found hanged beneath London's Blackfriars Bridge last June, the shock of the death was heightened by the revelation that followed: Mr. Calvi, with the support of the Vatican, had made $1.4 billion in unsecured loans to shadowy companies in Panama. It was a scandal of international proportions. ''Frontline,'' public television's documentary series, looks at the Calvi affair tonight in ''God's Banker,'' which it has produced in association with the BBC. It will be seen at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

headline.main: TV: 'FRONTLINE' LOOKS INTO ITALIAN BANKER'S DEATH

docs.snippet: ''Thank God, you're still well,'' a woman at the next table said to Jorge Batlle Ibanez in a restaurant here.   Outside, a kiosk owner stuck his head out from among the magazines and newspapers to call out, ''I'm with you, Mr. Batlle.'' A toll taker,...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Thank God, you're still well,'' a woman at the next table said to Jorge Batlle Ibanez in a restaurant here. Outside, a kiosk owner stuck his head out from among the magazines and newspapers to call out, ''I'm with you, Mr. Batlle.'' A toll taker, giving Mr. Batlle a thumbs-up sign, refused to take his money. So goes the daily round of testaments to the extraordinary political popularity of this member of Uruguay's most famous political family - extraordinary because in the eyes of Uruguay's 10-year-old military regime, Mr. Batlle does not exist politically.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marife Hernandez began a television program, ''The Puerto Rican New Yorker,'' in 1970 and went on to become one of that community's most active representatives. Now she's chief executive of ''Britain Salutes New York, 1983,'' called the largest British cultural festival ever staged outside the United Kingdom.

byline.original: By Laurie Johnston and Robin Herman

docs.snippet: To Argentines who flock here during the summer months of January through March, this Uruguayan beach resort of sparkling sand and spectacular sunsets is simply the ''Punta.''   Few Uruguayans make the trip, although Punta del Este, situated at the...
docs.lead_paragraph: To Argentines who flock here during the summer months of January through March, this Uruguayan beach resort of sparkling sand and spectacular sunsets is simply the ''Punta.'' Few Uruguayans make the trip, although Punta del Este, situated at the broad mouth of the Rio de la Plata, about 200 miles east of Buenos Aires, is their nation's most developed resort. Many Uruguayans say they prefer to avoid the Argentines, who are noticeable by their harsh Spanish and skimpy bathing suits. Local officials estimate that Argentines make up more than 85 percent of the summer population, which normally peaks at more than 100,000. Ninety percent of the land is said to be owned by Argentines.

headline.main: URUGUAY RESORT FEELS COLD WIND FROM ARGENTINA

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: On his way from Mexico City to Stockholm to receive the 1982 Nobel Prize in Literature, and again on the way back, Gabriel Garcia Marquez stopped over in Cuba to see his close friend and political mentor, Fidel Castro. The Colombian novelist is a...
docs.lead_paragraph: On his way from Mexico City to Stockholm to receive the 1982 Nobel Prize in Literature, and again on the way back, Gabriel Garcia Marquez stopped over in Cuba to see his close friend and political mentor, Fidel Castro. The Colombian novelist is a frequent traveler to Havana, but these two visits took on special significance: He was emphasizing his political identification with Cuba at the moment of his greatest literary glory. In contrast, Octavio Paz, the Mexican poet and essayist, has not visited Havana since the 1959 Cuban revolution. He once sympathized with the announced objectives of the new regime, but became disenchanted when, in his words, the revolution was ''confiscated'' by Marxists. He now considers the Cuban people no more fortunate than they were before the overthrow of the rightist dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista. Garcia Marquez and Paz live seven miles apart in Mexico City and are great admirers of each other's writing, but they are no longer close friends. Politics, their common obsession, has divided them. They have become symbols of the two opposing views in the rising political debate among Latin America's intellectuals.

headline.main: REVLOUTION AND THE INTELLECTUAL IN LATIN AMERICA

byline.original: By Alan Riding; Alan Riding is chief of The New York Times's bureau in Mexico City

docs.snippet: FROM a statistical perspective, it seems safe to assert that withoutL atin America, the international debt crisis would not exist.  By the end of 1982, eight Latin American countries had gross e xternal debts of nearly $300 billion -about 55 percent...
docs.lead_paragraph: FROM a statistical perspective, it seems safe to assert that withoutL atin America, the international debt crisis would not exist. By the end of 1982, eight Latin American countries had gross e xternal debts of nearly $300 billion -about 55 percent of the $550 b illion that 50 developing nations owed to foreign creditors at y ear's end, according to figures from the Morgan Guaranty Trust C ompany. By themselves, Argentina, Brazil and Mexico accounted for $ 202.5 billion. Fresh commercial loans and billion-dollar aid packages and reschedulings from the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral institutions have eased the international crisis for the time being. But the Latin American debt problem is far from solved. ''This is a situation requiring almost continuous nervous attention on the part of everyone involved,'' said Robert V. Roosa, a partner at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. ''Enough has been done in the last eight or nine months to put the framework in place for handling their excessive debt burden, but there is no room for euphoria.''

headline.main: THE MAZE OF LATIN AMERICA'S DEBT

docs.snippet: Less than two weeks after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices by $5 a barrel, some oil exporting nations are starting to line up for money from the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks.   The actions of such...
docs.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices by $5 a barrel, some oil exporting nations are starting to line up for money from the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks. The actions of such countries as Venezuela, Ecuador and Nigeria follow reports that Mexico, a non-OPEC member that recently signed a $10 billion I.M.F.-designed loan package, may need an additional $2 billion this year because of lost oil revenues. Mexico could see its oil revenues fall by $3 billion this year as a result of lower oil prices, some officials have estimated. But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and international monetary authorities based here insisted last week that the situation is manageable.

headline.main: OIL CUTS LEAD EXPERTS TO SEEK AID

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The scandal of Chile is that so many of its best and bravest have been forced to live in exile for nearly a decade. So unforgiving is the Pinochet dictatorship that last week it barred a former Foreign Minister from his mother's funeral.
docs.lead_paragraph: The scandal of Chile is that so many of its best and bravest have been forced to live in exile for nearly a decade. So unforgiving is the Pinochet dictatorship that last week it barred a former Foreign Minister from his mother's funeral.

headline.main: Topics; Hemisphere Diversions; Colder in Chile

docs.snippet: Suriname, Nicaragua, Cuba and Haiti received harsh criticism in a report on freedom of the press and information that was approved last month by the Inter American Press Association.   The report, which provided generally brief assessments of press...
docs.lead_paragraph: Suriname, Nicaragua, Cuba and Haiti received harsh criticism in a report on freedom of the press and information that was approved last month by the Inter American Press Association. The report, which provided generally brief assessments of press freedoms in each of 26 nations, was prepared by the association's Committee on Freedom of the Press and Information for a meeting of the organization in Manzanillo, Mexico. The Miami-based group represents more than 300 publishers and editors from North, South and Central America and the Caribbean. The harshest and briefest condemnation was reserved for Haiti, of which the report said simply, ''There is no freedom of the press.''

docs.snippet: Relatives of 166 British soldiers killed in the Falkland Islands left Britain today on a pilgrimage to the remote South Atlantic battleground where their husbands, fathers and sons died a year ago.
